noun.description: A place where someone or something is located or has been put.
examples: the distress call had given the ship's position
Mrs. Snell had taken up her position on the bottom step of the stairs

noun.description: A particular way in which someone or something is placed or arranged.
examples: he moved himself into a reclining position
a cramp forced her to change position

noun.description: A situation or set of circumstances, especially one that affects one's power to act.
examples: the company's financial position is grim
we felt we were not in a position to judge the merits of the case

noun.description: A person's point of view or attitude toward something.
examples: Ill never accept his position on censorship

noun.description: An investor's net holdings in one or more markets at a particular time; the status of an individual or institutional trader's open contracts.
A proposition laid down or asserted; a tenet or assertion.

verb.description: Put or arrange (someone or something) in a particular place or way.
examples: he pulled out a chair and positioned it between them
she positioned herself on a bench

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin positio(n-), from ponere to place. The current sense of the verb dates from the early 19th century.
